title: 112_hr3163
content: The "Easy Voting Act of 2011" establishes a minimum early voting period for jurisdictions conducting early voting, amending the Help America Vote Act of 2002 to include requirements for states permitting early voting. The "Easy Voting Act of 2011" mandates a 14-day early voting period (including weekends) for states allowing early voting for Federal elections, starting January 1, 2012. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to the enforcement section of the Help America Vote Act of 2002. Starting January 1, 2012, the "Easy Voting Act of 2011" requires a 14-day early voting period for Federal elections. A conforming amendment is made to the enforcement section of the Help America Vote Act of 2002. The "Easy Voting Act of 2011" mandates a 14-day early voting period for Federal elections starting January 1, 2012. A new section, SEC. 303B, prohibits states from requiring state-issued identification for voting or registering to vote. The Easy Voting Act of 2011 mandates a 14-day early voting period for Federal elections starting January 1, 2012. An election official cannot require a State-issued identification for voting or registering to vote in any Federal election. The Easy Voting Act of 2011 mandates a 14-day early voting period for Federal elections starting January 1, 2012. States must comply with the requirement under section 303(b) for individuals registering to vote by mail to present identification when casting a ballot. The effective date for compliance is January 1, 2012. SEC. 303C. ELECTION DAY REGISTRATION AND CHANGE OF ADDRESS SERVICE. This section requires states to provide same-day voter registration and change of address services on election day. On election day, each State must allow individuals to register and vote at the polling place if they meet the qualifications. The State must allow individuals to register and vote at the polling place on election day if they are qualified. If a registered voter moves within the State without updating their address, they can provide the new address at the polling place to cast a vote in a Federal election. State election official must allow individuals to update their address at the polling place to vote in a Federal election, without needing to use a provisional ballot. The bill requires states to allow individuals to update their address at the polling place to vote in a Federal election using a regular ballot, with exceptions for states without voter registration requirements for Federal elections. Voter registration forms must be transmitted to state election officials at the polling place. The bill mandates that voter registration forms or change of address forms provided at the polling place during a Federal election must be transmitted to the State election official along with the cast ballots. States must comply with this requirement starting January 1, 2012. Each State must comply with the requirements of this section starting January 1, 2012. Section 303C of the Act allows for Election Day registration and change of address services. This applies to early voting sites as well, where individuals can register to vote in the same manner as required on Election Day. The State must allow individuals to register to vote and provide change of address services at early voting polling places, following the same procedures as on Election Day.
